title: 106_s2463
content: The Act titled "National Death Penalty Moratorium Act of 2000" establishes a moratorium on the death penalty. Congress finds that death sentences are disproportionately imposed on the poor and certain racial and ethnic groups, with African-Americans being overrepresented in executions and on death row. The death penalty system in the United States shows racial disparities in capital prosecution, with a high percentage of African-American and Hispanic defendants selected for capital punishment. Additionally, prisoner appeals have been limited by the Supreme Court since 1976, increasing the risk of wrongful imprisonment and execution. In 1996, new legislation limited Federal court review of death penalty appeals and reduced public funding for legal aid services for death row prisoners, making it difficult for them to appeal their convictions and death sentences. Federal and State death penalty executions are halted until Congress reviews the final recommendations of the National Commission on the Death Penalty. The Commission's guidelines and procedures must be either implemented or rejected through legislation repealing this section. The National Commission on the Death Penalty is established with 15 members appointed by the President. The Commission includes prosecutors, defense attorneys, judges, law enforcement officials, and individuals with expertise in relevant matters. The National Commission on the Death Penalty is established with 15 members appointed by the President, including individuals from various sectors with knowledge in relevant matters. The President must ensure a balanced membership with differing opinions on the death penalty. Initial appointments should be made within 30 days of the Act's enactment. Members serve for a specified period and vacancies are filled accordingly. The Commission shall be appointed within 30 days of the Act's enactment and members serve for life. Vacancies do not affect the Commission's powers and are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Commission must hold its first meeting within 30 days of all initial members being appointed and meetings are called by the Chairperson. A majority of members constitute a quorum for business, with the President designating a Chair. The Commission adopts rules and procedures for its proceedings. SEC. 202. Duties of the Commission: The Commission is responsible for adopting rules and procedures for its proceedings. The Commission is mandated to conduct a comprehensive study on the administration of the death penalty, focusing on issues like racial disparities, geographical and income-based disproportionality in sentencing, and the quality of legal representation for capital defendants. The Commission is studying various issues related to the death penalty, including the competency of counsel, wrongful convictions, federal government seeking death penalty in states without it, independent judgment in post-conviction proceedings, sentencing of mentally retarded and juvenile offenders to death, and access to forensic evidence for those sentenced to death. The Commission is studying issues related to the death penalty, including access to forensic evidence and DNA testing for potential innocence. Guidelines and procedures will be established to ensure fair and impartial administration of the death penalty, minimize the risk of executing innocent individuals, and prevent racial discrimination in its application. The Commission will submit a preliminary report within 1 year and a final report within 2 years of the Act's enactment, containing findings, conclusions, and recommendations for legislation and administrative actions to prevent racial discrimination in the death penalty. The Commission has powers outlined in Section 203. The Commission has the authority to obtain information from Federal and State agencies, use postal services, accept gifts, and conduct hearings as outlined in Section 203. The Commission has the authority to issue subpoenas for witnesses and documents, with enforcement through district courts. Failure to comply may result in contempt charges. The court can issue a writ of habeas corpus ad testificandum to produce a person in custody before the Commission. Witness allowances and fees will be paid according to the provisions of title 28, United States Code. SEC. 204. COMMISSION PERSONNEL MATTERS. Members of the Commission serve without compensation but are allowed travel expenses. The Chairperson can appoint an executive director and additional staff without following civil service laws. Compensation for staff can be determined by the Chairperson without specific regulations. The Commission can appoint personnel without following civil service laws, with pay rates capped at level V of the Executive Schedule. Federal employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement. The Chairperson can also procure temporary services at specified rates. The Commission will terminate 90 days after submitting its report. It can spend up to $850,000 for its operations, funded by the Department of Justice.
